data.proxyObjectName: black stainless steel water bottle with 'TESLA' branding
data.utilizationMethod: Grip the narrow neck of the bottle (≈2–3 cm diameter) as though it were the mug handle, keeping the heavier body hanging below your hand.  This offset mass reproduces the mug’s forward roll when lifted.  Pitching the wrist 30–70° gives clear inertial resistance from the full bottle, simulating the sensation of tilting a full mug toward the mouth.

data.proxyObjectName: green plush turtle shell with white rim
data.utilizationMethod: Clamp both hands around one edge of the plush shell and swing the opposite, padded bulk forward as the axe head.  The size and moderate weight offer noticeable inertia while the soft impact surface lets users safely practice the abrupt stop of a virtual chop.

data.proxyObjectName: blue rectangular Pilot V Board Master whiteboard eraser box
data.utilizationMethod: Clasp one narrow end of the box, letting the box’s bulk project outward as the striking head. Because the box is wider than your grip, each downward tap delivers a solid stop—useful for simulating flat-faced mallet blows in VR.

data.proxyObjectName: black and silver telescopic selfie stick with phone holder clamp
data.utilizationMethod: Collapse the pole to its shortest length and hold the foam-covered handle. Orient the phone clamp forward and downward; its claw-like curve substitutes for the sickle blade, while the collapsed pole provides moderate forward inertia. Perform elbow-driven pulling arcs, feeling the clamp drag through the air like a hooked cutter.
